title: How to Zoom Out on a PC

steps.title: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out.
steps.content: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out. For example, if you want to zoom out on a website that's too big, click anywhere on the website. If you want to zoom out on your desktop, just click your desktop. This is one of the quickest and easiest ways to zoom out, especially if you don't have a mouse with a scroll wheel. This method won't work in all apps, such as Microsoft Word . It will work in all web browsers, on your desktop, and in various other Windows apps.

steps.title: Press and hold the Ctrl key, then press the - (minus) key.
steps.content: Press and hold the Ctrl key, then press the - (minus) key. It's at the top of the keyboard between the number zero and the equal sign. Each time you press the minus key while holding down the Ctrl key, you'll be zooming out a bit furtherâ€”this makes everything in the selected area appear smaller so you can see more at once. To zoom back in, hold down Ctrl and press the + (plus) key instead.

steps.title: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out.
steps.content: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out. For example, if you want to zoom out on a website that's too big, click anywhere on the website. If you want to zoom out on your desktop, just click your desktop. If your mouse has a physical scroll wheel that allows you to scroll up and down in various windows, you can use that same scroll wheel to quickly zoom in and out. This method should work on any website, on the desktop, and in most (but not all) apps.

steps.title: Press and hold the Ctrl key.
steps.content: Press and hold the Ctrl key. Keep holding the key down.

steps.title: Scroll the mouse wheel downward.
steps.content: Scroll the mouse wheel downward. As you scroll down, the view of the selected page or window will change to display more at once. To zoom back in, hold down the Ctrl key and scroll upward instead.

steps.title: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out.
steps.content: Click the page or location on which you want to zoom out. For example, if you want to zoom out on a website that's too big, click anywhere on the website. If you want to zoom out on your desktop or a photo, click your desktop or the photo instead. If you have a laptop with a touch/trackpad or a touch screen, you can do a "reverse-pinch" gesture to zoom in or out in various apps, as well as on the desktop. This is pretty easy, and will work in most apps (including Microsoft Office apps). Still, some apps may not support this gesture. If you've disabled gestures on your trackpad or on your touchscreen, this feature won't be available. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Place two fingers together on the trackpad or touchscreen.
steps.content: Place two fingers together on the trackpad or touchscreen. You'll want to have two fingers right next to each other (they can be touching) right on the trackpad. If you're zooming in on something particular on a touchscreen monitor, place your fingers together right over the area you want to zoom out on. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Spread your two fingers apart on the trackpad.
steps.content: Spread your two fingers apart on the trackpad. As your two fingers move away from one another on the trackpad or touchscreen, the selected page or app will zoom out to display more content. [3] X Research source If this motion sounds confusing, just think of it as the opposite of pinching! Pinch two fingers together to zoom back in.

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings .
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . You'll find this gear icon in your Windows Start menu. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source This method will help you decrease the size of your icons, text, apps, and other details throughout Windows (rather than in a single app or document). Use this method if everything on the screen is too large, not just a certain app, website, or file.

steps.title: Click System.
steps.content: Click System . It's the first icon in your settings.

steps.title: Click the Display tab.
steps.content: Click the Display tab. It may open by default, but if it doesn't, click Display at the top of the left column.

steps.title: Click the menu under "Change the size of text, apps, and other items."
steps.content: Click the menu under "Change the size of text, apps, and other items." It's the first drop-down menu under "Scale and layout" in the right panel. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source The current zoom level is the percentage that's selected in the menu right now. The default size varies depending on your resolution.

steps.title: Select a smaller number.
steps.content: Select a smaller number. To zoom out everywhere (making the details smaller to show more on the screen), choose a percentage that's smaller than the one previously selected. For example, if 150% was selected, you could try 125% to zoom out a little bit, or 100% to zoom out even more. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source The screen will automatically adjust when you choose a different size. Depending on the apps you're using, you may need to close and reopen some of them to reflect your changes.

steps.title: Adjust the resolution (optional).
steps.content: Adjust the resolution (optional). The "Display resolution" menu contains your screen resolution , which should be set to an appropriate resolution for your screen size. In most cases, the highest resolution will already be selected (and the word "Recommended" will appear next to it). If you click the menu and there's a higher resolution listed, you can try selecting it to increase the amount of details you see on the screen (which makes everything smaller). [7] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you like the change you've made, click Keep changes when prompted. If it doesn't look right, click Revert instead.
